none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. A. Alexander, July 4, 1877
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. A. Alexander, July 4, 1877
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 18 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: A personal letter from W. A. Alexander in Crisfield, Maryland to Louis L. McInnis describing his missionary and religious work among lower-class communities on the Eastern Shore. Alexander discusses his travels visiting homes destitute of Scripture, his observations of Methodist and Presbyterian religious practices, and updates on mutual acquaintances pursuing religious vocations. The letter also includes commentary on commencement proceedings at what appears to be a university (likely Princeton), faculty matters, and Alexander's impressions of cultural differences he encounters in his work among island communities.

body.value:
J. A. VANDEGRIFT & CO.
(SUCCESSORS TO GEO H. HOLLIS.)
DEALER IN
Stoves, Tin-ware, Hardware, Hollow-ware
AND HOUSE FURNISHING GOODS,

Crisfield, Md. July 4 1877

Mr L. L. McInnis.          Dear Mac Your card came
to hand to day. & I will reply by letter as my hand is in &
I am not disposed to be ceremonious about replies. I suppose you
thought I had gotten away from this part of the country. No. Crisfield
is my general headquarters for all summer, & if I go elsewhere
my mail is forwarded from this place. I heard from Bigger today.
All of a sudden, he run upon his Presbytery and was licensed
last week — Now Parson Bigger. I guess Old Ray will persist still
more now that his fiddle be thrown away. He is at home. I
heard from Lewis Green, who is passing his summer at leisure, awaiting
the winter season for Cotton Trade. Story is preaching at Madison C.H.
Va. My work progresses moderately, — is monotonous & affords
but little subject for Comment. Furthermore it is hard, I go on
foot from house to house to look up those destitute of the Holy Scrip
ture. Hence my work is among the lower classes. But they
have to be reached & the work devolves upon me. I am learning
much country slang, & meet a dozen times a day persons who
"haint got no larnin", "not-high larnt, but larnt a little".
I long for the time when I get back to my office & my books at P.

**Transcription Process Deep Dive** Okay, here's how I approached this transcription, breaking down each stage: First, I assessed the task. I needed to transcribe text from an image of a handwritten letter, maintaining its original spelling and punctuation, and preserving the layout, including paragraphs, marginalia, and the use of specific HTML tags. I also had to interpret the handwriting, making a note of any uncertainties, which I marked with a `[?]`. And I was *only* to transcribe the text itself, no commentary was permitted. Next came the image analysis. The letter was on pre-printed business stationery from J.A. Vandegrift & Co., successors to Geo H. Hollis. The printed header was in several fonts, including a large serif font for the company name, smaller serifs for the "successors" and "dealer in" lines, and an ornate Gothic/Blackletter style for the product list ("Stoves..."). This was important because I had to decide how to handle the capitalization and font styles in the HTML. The handwritten date and location were "Crisfield, Md. July 4 1877." The salutation was "Mr L. L. McInnis. Dear [word]". The body was dense, cursive, and a bit cramped, with ink that contrasted reasonably well but wasn’t always crystal clear. I took note of the content – the writer received a card, mentioned being in Crisfield, and relayed news about "Bigger," "Old Ray," "Lewis Green," and "Story," who were all people known to the writer. The writer also described their work: visiting houses looking for people lacking the Holy Scripture, dealing with the "lower classes," and learning "country slang". Then, I meticulously transcribed the text, step-by-step. The header was straightforward. The company name and "dealer in" lines were in standard capitalization; the "Stoves..." line needed to be in bold and capitalized because it was in an ornate font. I decided to make it bold as I couldn't replicate the specific font style. The date was "Crisfield, Md. July 4 1877." The trickiest part was the salutation. It started with "Mr L. L. McInnis." The handwriting after "Dear" was unclear. I carefully compared letters like "r" and "c" in other words in the text. I initially read it as "Dear Mac" (likely a nickname for McInnis). But, re-examining the cursive, the squiggle could be anything. Given the recipient's name, "Dear Mac" seemed most logical. Still, I noted my uncertainty and that the squiggle could also be a "c" or even an "r", forming "Dear Mc" or "Dear Mr". It seems to read "Dear Mr". But it's odd "Dear Mr. Your card" without an actual name attached. So I stuck with "Dear Mac". The body was transcribed bit by bit, paying close attention to unclear letters or punctuation. I made decisions based on context. "Run upon" seemed more likely than "ran upon," and "be thrown" was chosen over "is thrown" based on the handwriting. The hyphenation was marked for words like "Holy Scrip-ture". Quotes were carefully transcribed, ensuring I understood their usage for colloquialisms like "'haint got no larnin'". I refined the interpretations iteratively. I re-checked the salutation, and, more and more, it looked like "M [squiggle]", and, again, "Mac" seemed the only contextually likely choice, despite how ambiguous it looked. I looked closely at "ceremonious about replies &c" and the ampersand symbol was more like an `&c` (et cetera). I considered formatting the HTML. I bolded the header and used paragraph tags (`

`) to structure the text. I used line break tags (`
`) to match the visual letter structure. I drafted the transcript, applying the HTML tags, and then double-checked everything. I revisited the salutation, the "replies &c", the quotes, the hyphenated words, the use of quotes, and the letter structure, to make the rendering consistent. The formatting and layout were a primary focus, especially in getting the addressee name. I revisited "Stoves..." again. It was a slightly trickier font, but I was confident in my capitalization. The "1877" was printed "187_" with a hand-written "7" after. I decided to write out "1877". I re-checked all quotes, punctuation, abbreviations, and any handwriting interpretation. I checked everything again, specifically "Dear Mac", the word "replies", the word "run", "fiddle be", and again re-evaluated "Madison" and "Story". I've

Have no opportunity- to read, that little to write. I hope you are
well & prosperous. What are are you Grinding, How is your
school. What studies do you pursue. How are Josh & Rich.
I am glad Your Father is on his old path again. He is much
liked among the week churches of our State. Dont fail to send
him & Mrs Allsworth my regards when you write. My father has
just written me an account of Commencement. Many Speakers
didnt know their parts. Gray (Dont know him) Got 1st medal
& Sullivan the 2nd. The Alumni Part seems to have
failed - or collapsed. Genl Woodford - ex Gov. of
N York was orator. It was through my efforts that
he was brought down. I met him at the Δ.Ψ. Reunion
in N Y Xmas, of wh. he is a member. Coming as a
Northern man he attracted large crowds & I hear an
unusual no of visitors, (prominent men) were on hand
drawn by him. I regarded it as a dubious experiment to
get him down, but it seems to have taken mightily among
them, Though snubbed, I still cherish our institution.
He made a most excellent Speech, so the writer
says. Charlton made they say a Splendid
Val - which he is capable of doing, if he tries.
Good. Good. The board read Gen Sears a lecture
on how to teach Math. They arraigned him for
being Snobbish & a drag to aspiring boys. Many
true friends of the Univ. have been working to this end
for some time

J. A. VANDEGRIFT & CO.
(SUCCESSORS TO GEO. H. HOLLIS.)
DEALER IN
Stoves, Tin-ware, Hardware, Hollow-ware
AND HOUSE FURNISHING GOODS,
Crisfield, Md.,...................................................187

D.D. was given to Craig of Holy Springs & J.S.
Moore of Texas, Presbyterians & 1 or two, to Meths, &
1 to Darnell of Lebanon. Creighton is preaching at Butler Pa. His bro. will
be at Princeton Sem. next term - from Tenn. perhaps A.E. also. As to day
is the 4th I am going to an ice cream festival, near, & cooling-
self internally, with cream. They have started the law
department again at Ox. Judge Warren as prof.
I swapped a testament for a Telemaque in French
the other day & have been reading in it a little. which
- the blame lie on old Jerry - is a little slow without
a lexicon. As it is near train time
please excuse my not filling this page
I have an aversion to leaving unwritten paper
in a letter, also to using a pencil, unless suddenly
deprived of a pen as is my case at present
Write soon As Ever Your
True friend
W. A. Alexander.

Dr Mo. I missed the train & will add more

**Transcription of Handwritten Letter** Okay, here's what I've got. I'm looking at this image, and first, the letterhead grabs my attention. It's a bit of a classic, right? The letterhead reads:

J. A. VANDEGRIFT & CO.

(SUCCESSORS TO GEO. H. HOLLIS.)

DEALER IN

Stoves, Tin-ware, Hardware, Hollow-ware

AND HOUSE FURNISHING GOODS,

Crisfield, Md., ..............................187

Now, the handwriting. It's pencil, and a little faded, which makes it a touch tricky to decipher. Looks like someone making a list, or taking notes. Here's what I've made out, line by line:

D.D. was given to Craig of Holy Springs & J.S.
Moore of Texas, Presbyterians & 1 or two, to Meths, &
1 to Darnell of Lebanon. Creighton is preaching at Butler Pa. His bro. will
[be] at Princeton Sem. next term - from Tenn. perhaps A.E. also. As to day
is the 4th I am going to an ice cream festival, near, & cooling-
self internally, with cream. They have started the law
department again at Ox. Judge Warren as prof.
I swapped a testament for a Telemaque in French
the other day & have been reading in it a little. Which
- the blame lie on old Jerry - is a little slow without
a lexicon. As it is near train time
please excuse my not filling this page
I have an aversion to leaving unwritten paper
in a letter, also to using a pencil, unless suddenly
deprived of a pen as is my case at present
Write soon As Ever Your
True friend
W. A. Alexander.
Dr Mo. I missed the train & will add more

It's a jumble of thoughts, but here's my read. It looks like he's recounting the distribution of Doctor of Divinity degrees (D.D.) to various people: Craig of "Holy Springs" (Holly Springs, Mississippi?), Moore from Texas (likely a Presbyterian connection), Darnell of Lebanon (Tennessee maybe, or Lebanon PA? It's not clear where Darnell is from), and then some Methodists. Then a note about Creighton preaching, his brother at Princeton Seminary. It looks like he mentions the 4th of July and an ice cream social. Then an academic feel with the law department starting again in Oxford, maybe Oxford Mississippi since he also mentions Holy Springs? Or maybe Oxford, England! I have to be careful not to make assumptions. It sounds like he swapped a testament for a book called "Telemaque" in French, and that he is reading it without a lexicon (dictionary). He ends apologetically due to being short on time before a train, and he hates leaving empty space on a letter. Then a signature "W.A. Alexander" and a postscript addressed to "Dr Mo". (Likely "Dear Mo" or a "Dr Mo"?) I've assumed "Dr Mo." is the most accurate reading, given the context.

Traveling by RR is no trouble to me as I have a pass ticket
Sent me by a U.S. Senator. With such men I corres-
pond & you should feel honored to receive a letter from
me, considering my associations. Do you ever
see any of your Miss friends – Hayes Finch &c?
I dont ever visit here, my travelling job is
opposed to it. and the ladies generally have no
culture. Where I stop in this town is one nice
young lady, though I have just discovered it, for
I never cultivated her acquaintance until
recently. I have come to the conclusion that
a cultured lady is a rara avis,

I went a week or two out to an adjoining
island, & while there preached an extempore sermon, on
5 minuts notice to the Methodist emotional illiterate people
What got me was that there was lots of shouting, clapping
holy laugh &c & a calling of mourners & their suffocating
& crowding them until I got almost disgusted. I must
disparage the Meth. doctrine that the anxious seat
is the place to make terms of peace with God. The excitement
of the place is opposed to the consideration the subject
demands. Yet many will maintain that this is the wicket-gate
through which one must needs pass. I was much delighted with
their Waterman-habits. They have no buggies wagons roads
& but a few horses for plowing on the island, They go in Canoes
[Margin: or Cunners as they call them]

[Margin: studied much, salt water swimming & going to church in Canada]

**Okay, here's the transcription process, as I see it, with all the careful consideration I've put into each decision:** First, I had to figure out what was being asked of me: take this image of a handwritten letter and turn it into a perfectly accurate transcript, warts and all, including those little marginal notes. I needed to keep the original formatting (like paragraph breaks), the spelling, the punctuation, and handle any tricky spots with the proper notation. I knew this was older handwriting, so deciphering would be the key. So, I started with a good look at the image. It's cursive, a bit tilted, but mostly readable. There was also this vertical text in the margin, which looked like it might be just as important as the main body. It seemed like personal correspondence from the late 1800s or early 1900s, with travel, social stuff, and a church service on an island being the main topics. The plan was to go line-by-line. I started at the top. The first line was a challenge. That initial word, it looked like "franking," but I had to re-read it. Contextually, I thought "Traveling by RR" (Railroad) made the most sense. Then there was this word, ending in "ticket." I kept seeing "Justicket," "freeticket," even "passticket." It was tricky, but I finally realized it was most likely "pass ticket," given the context of a Senator and travel, I needed to make that 'p' connection. Then I moved to the next lines. "Sent me by a U.S. Senator." Okay, now the "pass" made sense because I remembered that Senators give railroad passes. I saw phrases like "rara avis," and "wicket-gate," and "extempore sermon," and it all started to come together. In the margins, there was "or Cunners as they call them". That had to do with the "Canoes" mentioned earlier. The other marginal text I made out to be "studied much, salt water swimming & going to church in Canada." I had to think how that related. Then, line by line, I reviewed individual words. "job" vs. "gab". After lots of squinting, I settled on "job" because the sentence made sense in the context of travel, and the "j" seemed clearer than the "g." Also, I checked "Sent" in the second line. Even though it looked like "Lent", "Sent" makes more sense, grammatically, and contextually. The writing was a bit sloppy. "Pass" ticket kept tripping me up. The "p" loop was faint. The word looked like "free". I also checked the marginalia. I decided to make "or Cunners as they call them" part of the sentence about canoes, but to leave "studied much" at the end, as a general note. I had to look at "minuts" - misspelled - and "Waterman-habits." It looked like "U.S. Senator," and "Hayes Finch." Finally, I got to the formatting. HTML and line breaks. Paragraphs. It was pretty easy after all that careful reading. I wrapped things up, and double-checked against the image to make sure I hadn't missed anything. Then, I was finally ready to share my final transcript.

Traveling by RR is no trouble to me as I have a pass ticket
Sent me by a U.S. Senator. With such men I corres-
pond & you should feel honored to receive a letter from
me, considering my associations. Do you ever
see any of your Miss friends - Hayes Finch &c?
I dont ever visit here, my travelling job is
opposed to it. and the ladies generally have no
culture. Where I stop in this town is one nice
young lady, though I have just discovered it, for
I never cultivated her acquaintance until
recently. I have come to the conclusion that
a cultured lady is a rara avis,
I went a week or two out to an adjoining
island, & while there preached an extempore sermon, on
5 minuts notice to the Methodist emotional illiterate people
What got me was that there was lots of shouting, clapping
holy laugh &c & a calling of mourners & their suffocating
& crowding them until I got almost disgusted. I must
disparage the Meth. doctrine that the anxious seat
is the place to make terms of peace with God. The excitement
of

If it will cause no irreverent smile, I will tell you of my
fix, that Sunday, weather warm, so that by Thursday my clothes are
dirty, collar, sh. bosom, pants, all dilapidated. A chance presented
itself for me to go over to Smith's (CaptJohn) Island suddenly & I had no time to
change garb, I worked Friday & Sat & Sunday went 3 miles in a
Canoe to church, Sitting on the edge of the vessel a big wave wet
my seat, my undersitting (not standing) My coat was of the Seymour
cut, (the one I was bumped in). Torn & sowed in back, & torn a little
& not sewed under arm, not shaved in 2 or 3 weeks. When they were about
to start, the old exhorter (preacher not there) eyed me in the Amen Corner &
took me, will or nil, into the pulpit to do the sermon. He took
a quarter of an hour talking money matters to the people & in the
meantime I decided to talk on what Jack Wheat lectured
to us one day — The comparison Paul makes between the Races
at Olympic games & the Christian life. I believe that I
was acceptable to them & made them understand
the points of analogy. For in the experience meeting which
followed, the old Class leader kept rehashing my points
showing that he had imbibed them None could tell
their experience without dissolving into tears.

The less intelligence prevails among a people,
the more the sensibilities come into play, in
place of intellect — in Religion. Doubtless
your observation with has shown the same thing to
you — It is observably so in the case of Negroes.
But I must stop this time for good.

Yrs Truly
W. A. Alexander

**Transcriptionist's Mindset: Analyzing and Crafting a Handwritten Letter's Digital Twin** Alright, here's how I'm going to approach transcribing this handwritten letter. First, I need to understand what's being asked of me: I'm acting as a transcriptionist, charged with taking an image of a handwritten text and rendering it as accurately as possible. That means preserving the original text, including any oddities or quirks, using HTML tags as requested, and maintaining the original paragraph structure and visual layout. I need to be as true to the original as I can, while keeping it readable. I see it's a personal letter, likely from the 19th century, written in cursive. It seems to describe a situation, a specific event involving going to church, and the writer's physical state during that visit. The letter has a main body in one paragraph, followed by a closing observation, and then the signature. I'm noting these details so I can maintain the intended structure in the HTML. Now, let's transcribe, line by line. I will be very meticulous about this! The first line is straightforward, but "sh. bosom" needs to be transcribed as it appears, even if the meaning isn't immediately obvious. The phrase "Capt John" looks like a correction or insertion, with "Capt" above "John", so I'll need to use superscript HTML for that. I'm seeing "sowed" which could be a misspelling of "sewed", but I need to transcribe it as it looks unless it's obviously illegible. There are a few words that seem crossed out: "highly" in line 16, and some words on line 17. The instructions say to interpret accurately, which includes these additions, deletions, corrections, and modifications to the original text. I must include these and not take the interpretation out of the original text. On "Line 24" it's a bit unclear. It reads "will has". This is grammatically incorrect, but I must transcribe exactly what I see. "Observably" looks like it might be misspelled but I must stick to the original, if legible. I'm now refining the transcription. Double-checking "sh. bosom", it's clear as day. "Undersitting" is a bit playful, but very legible. I had to look closely at "sowed". It does look like "sowed" from the visual, not "sewed". The name "Jack Wheat" is likely correct. "Will has" on line 24. It does not look like "hath". I have to transcribe "will has", even if it reads incorrectly. The text is in a clear hand. I'm going to omit deleted words in my rendering, if that can be shown. It's legible but still crossed out. I need to format the final transcription with HTML tags. I'll use `

` tags for paragraphs. Line breaks within the paragraphs will be represented by `
`. Superscript for "Capt" above "John". Then I will do a final polish for spelling accuracy. Now, I have to be extremely rigorous. Spelling, capitalization, and the preservation of the original layout, but must be readable. This means "sh. bosom" stays as is, along with "Seymour cut." "Will or nil" for willy-nilly and so on. Let's read the text line 16 and 17. The word "highly" is clearly struck, but legible. The text needs to be faithful to the original, so the word will be excluded. Also, the word before "experience" is illegible, and heavily crossed out. I am re-reading line 24: "Your observation with has shown". I'm convinced the visual is "with has" and it reads as such. I have double checked the signature and it seems correct: "W. A. Alexander". Ok, finally, I'm ready to generate the final output. The format should be clear and organized with the formatting tags.

Crisfield, Md., July 4, 1877

Mr. L. McInnis          Dear Mc

Your card came to hand today. & I will reply by
letter as my hand is in & I am not disposed to be ceremonious about replies etc.
I suppose you thought I had gotten away from this part of the country. No. Cris-
field is my general head quarters for all summer, & if I go elsewhere, my mail is
forwarded from this place. I heard from Bigger today. All of a sudden, he
run upon his presbytry and was licensed, last week - Now Parson Bigger. I gues O. W.
Ray will persist still more now that his fiddle be thrown away. He is at home.
I heard from Lewis Green, who is passing his summer at leisure, awaiting the
winter season for cotton trade. Story is preaching at Madison & Va. My
work progresses moderately - is monotomous & affords butlittle subject for comment.
Furthermore it is hard, I go on foot from house to house to look up those destitute
of the Holy Scripture, Hence my work is among the lower classes. But they have
to be reached & the work devolves upon me. I am learning much country slang &
meet a dozen times a day persons who "hain't got no larnin'" "Not high larnt,
but larnt a little." I long for the time when I get back to my office & my books
at P/rinceton/. I have no opportunity to read, & but little to write. _ I hope
you are well & prosperous. What axe are your grinding. How is your school.
What studies do you pursue. How are Josh & Rich. I am glad your Father is on
his old path again. He is much beliked among the week churches of our State.
Don't fail to send him & Mrs.Alsworth my regards when you write. My father
has just written me an account of Commencement. Many speakers didn't know their
parts. Gray (don't know him) got 1st medal & Sullivan the 2nd. The Alumni part
seems to have failed or collapsed. Genl. Woodford - ex Gov. of N. York was
orator. It was through my efforts that he was brought down. I met him at the
△ 4's Reunion in N. Y. Xmas. of wh/ich/ he is a member. Coming as a Northern man
he attracted large crowds & I hear an unusual no of visitors.

The goal is clear: capture the essence of this typewritten letter, paying meticulous attention to every detail, especially those handwritten additions. First up, the header. It's right-aligned and reads:

Crisfield, Md., July 4, 1877

Then we have the salutation:

Mr. L. McInnis      Dear Mc

Now, the main body of the letter, here we go:

Ray will persist still more now that his fiddle be thrown away. He is at home.
I heard from Lewis Green, who is passing his summer at leisure, awaiting the
winter season for cotton trade. Story is preaching at Madison & Va. My

Furthermore it is hard, I go on foot from house to house to look up those destitute

but larnt a little." I long for the time when I get back to my office & my books
at P/rinceton/. I have no opportunity to read, & but little to write. _ I hope

△ 4's Reunion in N. Y. Xmas. of wh/ich/ he is a member. Coming as a Northern man
he attracted large crowds & I hear an unusual no of visitors.

(prominent men) were on hand, drawn by him. I regarded it as a dubious experi-
ment to get him down, but it seems to have taken mightily among them. Though
snubbed, I still cherish our institution. He made a most excellent speech, so the
writer says. Charlton made they say a splendid val. - which he is capable of doing,
if he tries. Good. Good. The board read Gen. Sears a lecture on how to teach
Math. X They arraigned him for being toc snarlish & a drag to aspiring boys. Many
true friends of the Univ. have been working to this end for some time. D. D. was
given to Craig of Holy Springs & J. S. Moore of Texas, presbyterians & 1 or two, to
Meth. & 1 to Darnell of Lebanon. Creighton is preaching at Butter, Pa. His bro.
will be at Princeton Sem. next term - from Tenn. perhaps A. E. also. As today is
the 4th I am going to an iceXXXXXXX cream festival, , & cooling self internally
with cream. They have started the law department again at Ox/ford/. Judge Harmen as
prof.

I swapped a testament for a              in French the Xother day & have been
reading in it a little. which the blame lies on aX old Juny - is a little slow
XKA without a lexicon.

As it is near train time please excuse my not filling this page. I have an
aversion to leaving unwritten paper in a letter, also to using a pencil unless
suddenly deprived of a pin as is my case at present.

Write soon              As ever your

True friend

[Signature]
W. A. Alexander

Dear Me. I missed the train & will add more. Traveling by RR is no trouble to
me as I have a            ticket lent me by a U. S. Senator, with such men I correspond
& you should feel honored to receive a letter from me considering my associations.
Do you ever see any of our Miss friends Hayes , Finch etc? I don't ever visit
here, my                      is opposed to it and the ladies generally have no

As it is near train time please excuse my not filling this page. I have an aversion to leaving unwritten paper in a letter, also to using a pencil unless suddenly deprived of a pin as is my case at present.

Write soon As ever your

[Signature] True friend W. A. Alexander

Dear Me. I missed the train & will add more. Traveling by RR is no trouble to me as I have a ticket lent me by a U. S. Senator, with such men I correspond & you should feel honored to receive a letter from me considering my associations. Do you ever see any of our Miss friends Hayes , Finch etc? I don't ever visit here, my is opposed to it and the ladies generally have no

culture. Where I stop in this town is one nice young lady, though I have just
discovered it, for I never cultivated her adquaintance until recently. I have
come to the conclusion that a cultivated lady is a rara avis.

      I went a week or two out to an adjoining island & while there preached an
extempore sermon on 5 minutes notice to the Methodist emotional illerate people.
What got me was that there was lots of shouting, clapping, holy laugh etc & a
calling of mourners & than suffociating & crowding them until I got almost dis-
gusted. I must disparage the Meth. doctrine that the anxious seat is the place
to make terms of peace with God. The excitement of the place is opposed to the
consideration the subject demands. Yet many will maintain that this is the
wicket-gate through which one must needs pass. I was much delighted with their
waterman habits. They have no XXXXXXX Buggies, wagons, roads, & but a few horses for
plowing on the island. They go in canoes or cunners as they call them. I liked much
salt water swimming & going to church in canoes. If it will cause no irreverent
smile, I will tell you of my fix that Sunday. Weather warm so that by Thursday
my clothes are dirty, collar, sh/irt/ bosom, pants all dilapidated. A chance pre-
sents itself for me to go over to Smith's Capt. (John) Island suddenly & I had no
time to change garb. I worked Friday & Sat. & Sunday went 3 miles in a canoe to
church, sitting on the edge of the vessel a big wave wet my seat, my undersitting
(not standing) my coat was of the Seymour cut, (the one I was bumped in), torn and
sewed in back & torn a little & not sewed under arm, not shaved in 2 or 3 weeks.
When they were about to start the old exhorter (preacher not there) eyed me in
Amen Corner & took me, will or nil, into the pulpit to do the sermon. He took
a quarter of an hour talking money matters to the people & in the meantime I
decided to talk on what Jack Wheat lectured to us one day - the comparison Paul
makes between the Races at Olumpic games & the Christians life. I believe that

I was highly acceptable to them & made them understand the points of analogy,
for in the Experience Meeting which followed, the old classleader kept rehashing
my points showing he had imbibed them. None could tell their experience without
dissolving into tears.

The less intelligence prevails among a people the more the sXXXXXXXXXX
sensibilities come into play in place of intellect in Religion. Doubtless your
observation has shown the same thing to you - It is           so in the case
of Negroes.

But I must stop this time for good.

[Signature]

Yours Truly

W. A. Alexander
